title: Who's Afraid of AI and Robotics? | Monkey in the Machine Interview
You Are the Entrepreneur of Your Life  | Stephen Hicks | Universidad Francisco Marroquin
description:
This talk was given in the Fall of 2024 at the Universidad Francisco Marroquin in Guatemala City, Guatemala.

Stephen Hicks delivers an impassioned and data-rich talk about personal agency, mindset, and the revolutionary social, economic, and technological world we live in. Addressing students, especially psychology majors, Hicks argues that the most important concept for their generation is “entrepreneurship”—not merely in the business sense, but as a guiding philosophy for living a flourishing, autonomous life.  To illustrate the importance of entrepreneurial thinking, Hicks presents three compelling stories from medical history:

Dr. Hicks draws a conceptual link between philosophy and psychology via the notion of *mindset*. Our mindset—how we perceive ourselves, the world, and our possibilities—is central to how we navigate life. 

Hicks urges students not to drift through life or accept inherited scripts. Instead, they should embrace the freedom and responsibility of shaping their own destinies. The entrepreneurial mindset, deeply rooted in the revolutions of the modern era, is the key to not only surviving but thriving in an unpredictable world.

Stephen R. C. Hicks, Ph.D., is Professor of Philosophy at Rockford University, USA, and has had visiting positions at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C., University of Kasimir the Great in Poland, Oxford University’s Harris Manchester College in England, and Jagiellonian University in Poland.

title: The Influence of Nietzsche on 20th Century Thought and his continuing appeal
description:
This conversation with Chuong Nguyen, of the Unlicensed Philosophy podcast explores Friedrich Nietzsche's profound influence on modern philosophy, particularly postmodernism, and his complex relationship to Nazism. Hicks outlines how Nietzsche’s ideas on power, morality, and perspectivism laid groundwork for later thinkers like Foucault, and how these ideas—often misinterpreted—intersect with both Nazi ideology and contemporary political movements. He also refutes the claim that Nietzsche’s sister distorted his philosophy to align with Nazi beliefs. 

Stephen R. C. Hicks, Ph.D., is Professor of Philosophy at Rockford University, USA, and has had visiting positions at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C., University of Kasimir the Great in Poland, Oxford University’s Harris Manchester College in England, and Jagiellonian University in Poland.

title: Modernism, Postmodernism and the Way Forward | A Conversation | Stephen Hicks & Andy Schmitt
description:
This conversation between Andy Schmitt and Stephen Hicks spans a wide array of topics centered on the evolution of Western philosophy, especially the transition from modern to postmodern thought. They trace the rise of modern philosophy from the fifteenth-century globalization unleashed by Columbus, Gutenberg’s press, and Martin Luther’s insistence on individual Scripture reading, through the emergence of scientific reasoning, to the radical individualism of the Quakers. 

They examine how postmodern thinkers—Derrida, Foucault, Rorty, Lyotard—dismantled both religious and scientific claims to objective truth, ushering in an age of skepticism, expressive subjectivism, and cultural fragmentation. 

Hicks argues that this upheaval has provoked a three-way debate—between modernist, postmodern, and revived pre-modern perspectives—and contends that renewed engagement with philosophy can help us overcome today’s “culture wars.” 

Dr. Hicks was interviewed by Andy Schmitt on his Orthodoxy channel in December 2024.

Stephen R. C. Hicks, Ph.D., is Professor of Philosophy at Rockford University, USA, and has had visiting positions at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C., University of Kasimir the Great in Poland, Oxford University’s Harris Manchester College in England, and Jagiellonian University in Poland.

title: Karl Popper's Theory of Falsification | A Discussion with The Theory of Anything Podcast
description:
The Theory of Anything podcast is hosted by  Peter Johansen and Bruce Nielsen.   In their episode with Professor Stephen Hicks, they delve into epistemological topics, especially the philosophy of science, justification, Karl Popper's critical rationalism, and the developmental nature of knowledge.

In his response to their questions about falsification and fallibilism, Dr. Hicks stresses the importance of understanding the processes involved in cognition: sensation, perception, concept formation  and proposition and theory-building.

To their questions about the theory-ladenness of observation, Dr. Hicks argues from an empirical perspective that basic perception is pre-theoretical.

The conversation turns to the Kantian foundations in Karl Popper's and Thomas Kuhn's work.

The original podcast can  be found at: https://open.spotify.com/show/0bmymUJs50SVO1WkqfrccB?si=YIEzIfRTTFyS3oAcJ2BJmA

title: Immanuel Kant's Profound Impact on Art | A conversation with Stephen Hicks and Jan-Ove Tuv
description:
Late in the nineteenth century artists began to experiment with non-representational art.  Dr. Hicks traces this movement to Immanuel Kant's metaphysical and epistemological ideas as expressed in his 1781 work, Critique of Pure Reason.

Their conversation ranges over Kant's metaphysical ideas but also looks at his ideas of beauty and the sublime as expressed in The Critique of Judgment.

Craft and skill became less important and were replaced with notions of 'genius.'

title: Stephen Hicks on The Nietzsche Podcast
description:
Keegan Kjeldsen at Untimely Reflections spent an hour with Dr. Stephen Hicks.  The conversation started with Nietzsche's "Beyond Good and Evil".  It moved on to a discussion of the difference between Nietzsche's view of power and that of the postmodernists. 

Some time is spent discussing the differences between Nietzsche and Ayn Rand on individualism, ethics and truth.  It concludes with an assessment of modern academia.

title: The Enlightenment and its Opposition, Objective Morality, Israel | Wovenart Interview
description:
The Enlightenment, the  intellectual movement in the late 1600s and 1700s which promoted individual freedom and autonomy, equality, economic progress, religious tolerance and scientific progress changed to world.

The Enlightenment, however, has not been without foes.  Dr.. Hicks discusses the three movements which opposed the Enlightenment: religious traditionalists, socialists of various sorts and later, nihilists.  He discusses Israel within this context.  He also offers a naturalized or objective morality and what must be done to support the Enlightenment in these times.

title: Roger Scruton | The Meaning of Conservatism | Philosophers Explained | Stephen Hicks
description:
“Conservatism may rarely announce itself in maxims, formulae or aims. Its essence is inarticulate and its expression, when compelled, skeptical."

Roger Scruton (1944-2020), the British conservative philosopher,  took up conservatism after witnessing first hand the 1968 Paris student riots.  Unlike many contemporary conservatives who align with economic liberalism and free markets, Scruton articulates a conservatism rooted in authority, tradition, and social cohesion. He argues that the conservative instinct is rooted in a recognition of social continuity and the importance of inherited institutions. 

He focuses on conservatism's differences with liberalism, which he sees as its greatest foe.  Scruton critiques economic liberalism, but he also strongly opposes socialism and Marxism.

title: Robert Nozick | The Tale of the Slave | Anarchy, State and Utopia | Philosophers Explained
description:
"The fundamental question of political philosophy... is whether there should be any state at all.  Why not have anarchy?"

Robert Nozick (1938-2002) was an American philosopher who wrote on political philosophy, epistemology, decision theory and ethics.  The topic of this video is focused on a section of Nozick's  Anarchy, State and Utopia, in which he examines the nature and limits of slavery.

Nozick also critiques collectivist views that treat society as an entity above individuals, asserting that only individuals with their unique lives and values are real. He warns against using individuals for the supposed benefit of society, as this disrespects their autonomy.

A significant portion of the lecture is devoted to Nozick’s "Tale of the Slave," a thought experiment that examines various scenarios of control over an individual, from outright slavery to democratic systems. Through this, Nozick questions whether individuals are truly free under modern systems of taxation, paternalistic regulation, and democracy, drawing parallels to slavery. 

Philosophers, Explained covers major philosophers and texts, especially the great classics. In each episode, Professor Hicks discusses an important work, doing a close reading that lasts 40 minutes to an hour.

title: Sayyid Qutb | Milestones | Philosophers Explained | Stephen Hicks
description:
“If Islam is again to play the role of leader of mankind, then it is necessary that the Muslim community be restored to its original form.”

Qutb's "Milestones" (1964) is a short work in which the Islamic scholar calls for a return to original Islam.  In this essay, Qutb details the nature of the cause, the belief system, a plan of action and a call to action. 

"Fundamentally, it is a religious battle that Qutb is engaged in. It was not a political or an economic or a racial struggle. Instead, essentially it was a struggle between beliefs, either unbelief or faith, either jahiliyya or Islam.  Make one’s choice."

title: Ruth Benedict | Patterns of Culture | Philosophers Explained | Stephen Hicks
description:
“Standards, no matter in what aspect of behavior, range in different cultures, from the positive to the negative pole.”

Ruth Benedict (1887-1948) was an anthropologist  whose most important and influential work was Patterns of Culture (1934).  She makes an argument for engaging in anthropological investigations of cultures that are objective and nonjudgmental.

She further argues for "cultural relativism," that there are no universal moral standards from which to judge other cultures. Excerpts from this work have appeared  routinely in ethics anthologies.

title: Auguste Comte | Catechism of Positive Religion (1852) | Philosophers Explained | Stephen Hicks
description:
The topic of this video is the 1852 work "Catechism of Positive Religion" by Auguste Comte.  Comte (1798-1857) was a French philosopher, He is noted for coining the terms 'sociology' and 'altruism.'

One of his great concerns was the social breakdown that occurred during the French Revolution.  He saw the cause as the confusion of theological, metaphysical and scientific thinking that most people live by.  

Comte argued for a radical new philosophy of science: positivism, in which we no longer seek the causes of events we witness in the world, but limit our thinking  to discovering the actual laws of phenomena, that is to say, their invariable relations of succession and likeness. We are to measure what we can observe.

As applied to society, he concluded that morality was to consist in altruism or "live for others."  He also argued for strict regulation of society and human behavior.

title: Immanuel Kant | Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals |  Philosophical Explanations  Stephen Hicks
description:
In this video Dr. Hicks discusses Immanuel Kant's moral philosophy as presented in his 1785 work "Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals". 

Kant argues for a conception of morality based on duty and reason, rather than on desires, inclinations, or the pursuit of happiness or pleasure. He claims that the only thing that has unconditional moral worth is a "good will" - the will to do what is morally right simply because it is morally right and not for any other reason. 

Kant distinguishes between hypothetical imperatives, which are based on desires or goals, and categorical imperatives, which are moral laws that apply universally and unconditionally.

Kant contends that moral worth comes from acting out of duty to these categorical imperatives, not from the consequences of one's actions. Kant also argues that as rational beings, we must regard ourselves as legislators of the moral laws to which we are subject, rather than as merely passive subjects of those laws.

title: Socialism: Scientific or Religious? | Open College No. 54 | Stephen Hicks
description:
Socialism continues to attract followers more than a century after Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels first called for communist revolution in 1848.  Dr. Hicks sets out to investigate what is the attraction.

Early adherents of socialism were religious: monks and nuns, for instance.  But Marx and Engels offered what they called scientific socialism.  And yet, when you look at their writings, one has to ask: is it really based on facts, evidence, argumentation, experimentation, the whole apparatus of reason? Or is it ultimately a kind of faith commitment? 

In the end, Dr. Hicks likens their idealistic visions to a modernized, atheistic Garden of Eden.

For some time, Professor Hicks has been doing a philosophical analysis podcast on a wide range of contemporary topics.  It has been available on a number of other platforms.  It is now being offered on YouTube as well.  Its mission is to “ to explain the chaos.”

title: Objectivity for Actual Human Beings | Open College No. 50 | Stephen Hicks
description:
It is often said that we live in a post-truth age, that nothing can be known with any certainty and that we must give up notions of objectivity, truth and certainty.  In this podcast, Dr. Hicks sets out to make the case for objectivity.

He begins by looking at the underlying logical mistakes often made when  people argue against objectivity, namely false alternatives and implicit premises.  Hicks provides many examples of this kind of argumentation and dissects it.  

He offers a robust definition of objectivity at the end.

description:

title: Morality Without Gods | Open College No. 53 | Stephen Hicks
description:
Is morality natural or can it only be explained and justified by referring to a supernatural Being?  

The religious position is that nature cannot explain morality and therefore, we must believe in moral supernaturalism.  

The natural position is that humans make choices.  Reality provides a standard by which we can distinguish good from bad.  Therefore, morality is a natural phenomenon. 

On a personal level, should I decide on my core ethical values by 1) seeking direct communication with God or the gods or, 2) should I join an established religion and accept their code or, 3) simply copy the prevailing norms of society or, 4) should I independently judge what I consider to be good and bad? 

For some time, Professor Hicks has been doing a philosophical analysis podcast on a wide range of contemporary topics.  It has been available on a number of other platforms.  It is now being offered on YouTube as well.  Its mission is to “ to explain the chaos.”

title: Nietzsche and the Nazis (The Video)  Part 4
description:
This is the fourth and final part of a four part presentation of Dr. Stephen Hicks' book, Nietzsche and the Nazis.  The focus in this part is on the similarities and differences between the ideas of Nietzsche and those of the Nazis.  

Adolf Hitler and the Nazis claimed that the 19th century German philosopher, Friedrich Nietzsche (1844-1900), was one of their inspirations.  Were they right to do so?

This video investigates the thought of Friedrich Nietzsche as well as the political ideas of the Nazi Party.  To what extent did Nietzsche's philosophy provide a foundation for the horrors perpetrated by the Nazis?

title: Friedrich Nietzsche | The Greek State | Philosophers Explained | Stephen Hicks
description:
"... we must accept this cruel sounding truth that slavery is of the essence of
Culture..."

This essay was originally slated to appear in Nietzsche's first book The Birth of Tragedy.  In the essay, Nietzsche takes a critical look at modern liberal society and capitalism and concludes that its key ideals, 'the dignity of man' and the 'dignity of work', are illusions.  Instead, Nietzsche offers a look at his aristocratic understanding of the state.

The text can be found here:  https://www.stephenhicks.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Nietzsche-Greek-State-text.pdf

12:04 Man who works for his existence cannot become an artist.

19:55 The majority serves the minority.
20:40 Slavery is of the essence of culture

38:40 The consequences for culture and art

title: Voltaire | Letters on England-Politics, Philosophy, Science | Philosophers Explained | Stephen Hicks
description:
"The English are the only people upon earth who have been able to prescribe limits to the power of kings by resisting them..."

François-Marie Arouet (1694-1778), who later came to call himself Voltaire, was an intellectual of the French Enlightenment.  He was most famous for being the author of "Candide," which is still widely read to this day.  

He expressed his love of the tolerant English system of government and his criticism of French government in his "Letters on England."  In these later letters, Voltaire discusses how England has done what no people elsewhere have been able to do: limit the power of kings.  He also praises their economic policies as well as their use of science for purposes of public health.

The text can be found here: https://www.stephenhicks.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/08/Voltaire-Letters-on-England-text-full.pdf

description:
François-Marie Arouet(1694-1778), who later came to call himself Voltaire, was an intellectual of the French Enlightenment.  He was most famous for being the author of "Candide," which is still widely read to this day.  

He was a staunch critic of the Catholic Church in France and an advocate for freedom of speech and freedom of religion.

He expressed his love of the tolerant English system of government and his criticism of French government in his "Letters on England."

title: Thomas Kuhn | The Structure of Scientific Revolutions | Philosophers Explained | Stephen Hicks
description:
In this seminal work, Thomas Kuhn(1922-1996), argues that science has little to do with experimentation and the impartial collection and analysis of data.  Instead he argues that it has more to do with social and non-rational factors such as, accident and subjectivity.  The primary activity of most scientists, he says,  is doing "mop up work."

In the end, we may have to give up the notion of progress or truth in the sciences.

title: David Hume | A Treatise on Human Nature | Total Skepticism | Philosophers Explained | Stephen Hicks
description:
In this work, David Hume(1711-1776) argued that there were no rational grounds on which we could ever justify induction, causation, rational moral principles or a sense of self.  He talked instead of constant conjunction, bundles of sensations, custom, mental habit and the passions.

His skeptical ideas have had a lasting effect in the history of philosophy.  He inspired Immanuel Kant to awaken from his "dogmatic slumbers".

description:
This conversation between Brendan Graham Dempsey of Metamodern Spirituality and Dr. Hicks ranges over the metaphysical and  epistemological positions and ideas about human nature and values in the premodern, modern and postmodern eras.

Brendan Graham Dempsey explores the period after postmodernism, with a focus on creatively answering the meaning crisis of contemporary society.  More information can be found at https://www.youtube.com/@BrendanGrahamDempsey.

title: Francis Bacon | The Great Instauration | Philosophers Explained | Stephen Hicks
description:
Bacon wrote this work in a time of discovery, exploration, skepticism and religious turmoil.  

Bacon was critical of what passed for knowledge and reasoning in his time, as did Descartes.  Bacon argued for a new empiricism and the scientific method. This is a founding document of the scientific revolution.  It is a call for the use of induction.  Is he the father of modern philosophy?

The texts used in this video can be found at:  https://www.stephenhicks.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/08/BaconF-GREAT-INSTAURATION-text.pdf  and  https://www.stephenhicks.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/08/BaconF-NEW-ORGANON-text.pdf

title: Michel Foucault | History of Sexuality | Philosophers Explained | Stephen Hicks
description:
"The History of Sexuality" is Michel Foucault's examination of the history of discourse about and practice of sexuality over the past three centuries.  While sexuality was open in the seventeenth century and relatively closed through the Victorian era, it might appear that sexuality in the modern era has been open.  In fact, with the increase in the discourse about sexuality in modern times, Foucault argues we live in a new age of repression.

title: The Ethics of Entrepreneurship | The Entrepreneurism Series #1 | Stephen Hicks
description:
In this article, Dr. Hicks shows how the qualities of entrepreneurship form a code of ethics.   

It begins with an examination of three different ways to live life: charity, predation and entrepreneurism.  It then identifies the qualities of entrepreneurs and shows how their activities express a code of virtues.

In business, entrepreneurs have their own vision and take the initiative in making it real. What if we extend that mind-set and action-set to all of life?  In this series we explore what Entrepreneurism means for business, education, romance, and life in general.  You Are the Entrepreneur of Your Life. 

Here is a link to the article:  https://www.stephenhicks.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/07/jpe-hicks-what-business-ethics-can-learn.pdf

title: Jacques Derrida | Cogito and the History of Madness | Philosophers Explained | Stephen Hicks
description:
Jacques Derrida(1930-2004) was a French philosopher and is known as the father of deconstruction.  

In this critical essay, Derrida takes issue with Michel Foucault's treatment of Rene Descartes' treatment of reason and madness in his book, Madness and Civilization.  

In Madness and Civilization, Foucault argues that Descartes' treatment of madness was brief and incomplete, yet it nevertheless essentially silenced madness, insanity.

Derrida takes issue with Foucault's inconsistent rejection of the language of reason(of objectivity) and calls for a more comprehensive rejection.  "I philosophize only in terror, but in the confessed terror of going mad."

Here is a link to the text:  https://www.stephenhicks.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/DerridaJ-Cogito-History-Madness-text.pdf

Here is a link to the Philosophers Explained video on Descartes' "Meditations on the First Philosophy": https://youtu.be/w2-wQS01sDI

title: Derrick Bell | "Racial Realism" | Philosophers Explained | Stephen Hicks
description:
Derrick Bell (1930 –2011) was a legal scholar and a civil rights leader.  He is considered by many to be the founder of critical race theory.  The article "Racial Realism" is the text of a speech Bell gave at The University of Connecticut School of Law in 1991.

Bell begins by describing the legal realism movement of the early twentieth century in the US, which argued that precedence, property rights and objectivity were principles that serve a covert purpose.  He goes on to discuss the episodic nature of black progress and then argues for the abandonment of racial equality as a goal and its replacement with racial realism.

Here is a link to the text:  https://blog.richmond.edu/criticalracetheory/files/2019/02/Bell-Racial-Realism.pdf

title: The Philosophy of Money | Robert Breedlove interviews Stephen Hicks
description:

title: Bertrand Russell | "The Value of Philosophy" | The Problems of Philosophy | Philosophers Explained
description:
"The Value of Philosophy" is the last chapter of Bertrand Russell's  popular 1912 book "The Problems of Philosophy."  After discussing many issues of philosophy including, reality, existence, knowledge, induction, universals, truth and intuition, Russell looks at the question of whether philosophy is worth doing.  He concludes that it is.

title: What Should I do? | Ethical Reasoning in a Complex Situation | Open College No. 41 | Stephen Hicks
description:
This podcast examines a situation where you have made prior principled commitments to a position but now find yourself faced with practical circumstances which put those principles at risk.

The Payroll Protection Plan (PPP) was 2020 government program available to businesses and organizations, primarily in response to the economic damage done by Covid-19 slowdowns, shut-downs, and lock-downs.  

Advocates of the free market found themselves in difficult circumstances due to the shutdowns during Covid.   PPP was a life preserver offered by the government, the very entity which brought about the shutdowns.  Should you take the money or stand on principle?  Dr. Hicks looks at the arguments and principles--notably, justice, integrity and productiveness-- that must be considered in a complex situation.

This podcast is about Covid and PPP, but is about more than that.

More information here: 
https://www.stephenhicks.org/2020/07/12/what-would-dagny-do-ayn-rand-on-the-ppp/

https://www.stephenhicks.org/2020/07/11/analogies-a-primer-for-the-ppp-and-rrr-debate/

For some time, Professor Hicks has been doing a philosophical analysis podcast on a wide range of contemporary topics.  It has been available on a number of other platforms.  It is now being offered on YouTube as well.  Its mission is to “ to explain the chaos.”

title: If God exists, why is there evil in the world? | Open College No. 39 | Stephen Hicks
description:
The problem of the existence of evil in the world has long been a major argument against the existence of an infinite God who is omnipotent, omnibenevolent and omniscient. This question comes from the natural theology tradition, which is concerned with studying religious issues using reason and evidence.  The existence of God and the existence of evil in the world are seen to be incompatible.  

Dr. Hicks examines the argument and some of its counterarguments.  

He also looks at some of the final conclusions that are reached.  Some conclude the argument is sound.  Others see there is no way to answer the theodicy argument.  An act of faith is required.  Reason is inadequate.  Finally, other modify God's perfection or power.

title: Does God Exist? | The Teleological or Design Argument | Open College No. 38 | Stephen Hicks
description:
In this podcast, Dr. Hicks discusses the teleological or 'design' argument for the existence of God.

He begins with a discussion of the difference between revealed and natural theology. 

Revealed theology states all of the major truths are revealed by God to humanity, or perhaps to specific prophets, who then communicate them to the rest of humanity.  

Natural theology argues that God gave us various observational and rational faculties and we should use them to observe reality and argue to the existence of God. 

He examines in critical detail the following teleological argument for the existence of God:

1) The natural universe is orderly.
2) Complex order cannot arise from within nature itself.
3) Therefore, complex order requires an external or complex orderer.
4) This external orderer must have great power and intelligence.  
5) Therefore, there must be such an supernatural orderer.
6) His name is God.
7. Yes, He exists.

He concludes that the argument is worth serious study, but, in the end, it does not work.

For some time, Professor Hicks has been doing a philosophical analysis podcast on a wide range of contemporary topics.  It has been available on a number of other platforms.  It is now being offered on YouTube as well.  Its mission is to “ to explain the chaos.”

Stephen R. C. Hicks, Ph.D., is Professor of Philosophy at Rockford University, USA, and has had visiting positions at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C., University of Kasimir the Great in Poland, Oxford University’s Harris Manchester College in England, and Jagiellonian University in Poland.

title: Arguing about Religion | Open College No. 35 | Stephen Hicks
description:
To be human is to grapple with the big questions and the crucial values of life. Religion is a kind of philosophy, with answers to life's questions about who we are, where we came from, and what really matters. So, what should we think about religion?  

In this podcast, Dr. Hicks looks at the role that reason, evidence and logic and faith play in religious belief.  He concludes that the truth about religion can be known only by a mind that assesses the evidence and judges it independently.

title: Thomas Kuhn's De-structuring Science | Open College No. 37 | Stephen Hicks
description:
"The Structure of Scientific Revolutions" by Thomas Kuhn(1922-1996) is a seminal work in the philosophy of science.  It is also an often quoted text in postmodern theory.

Kuhn saw science as a discipline which lurches from normal science to revolutionary science.  Revolutionary science presents a new paradigm for seeing the world which is incommensurate with the current paradigm of normal science. On his view, there is not really any progress in science.  It is merely a series of lurches.

Dr. Hicks takes a look at this skeptical work which sees science as no more important, truthful or enlightening than any other belief system.  

For some time, Professor Hicks has been doing a philosophical analysis podcast on a wide range of contemporary topics.  It has been available on a number of other platforms.  It is now being offered on YouTube as well.  Its mission is to “ to explain the chaos.”

title: Is Democratic Socialism any better? | Open College No. 36 | Stephen Hicks
description:
Socialism is still seen by some as a social and political ideal.  Recognizing socialism's  brutal history, some argue for democratic socialism.  What is democratic socialism and can it protect us against dictatorial socialism?

Dr. Hicks examines the ideas of democratic socialism and its history.  He discusses how the primary focus on controlling economics and money soon slides into every other aspect of the lives of the people.  He concludes that democratic socialism--especially in the examples of Italian fascism and Nazi Germany--is but window dressing, a mere veneer.  Dictatorial socialism lies beneath.

For some time, Professor Hicks has been doing a philosophical analysis podcast on a wide range of contemporary topics.  It has been available on a number of other platforms.  It is now being offered on YouTube as well.  Its mission is to “ to explain the chaos.”

title: What do young socialists believe? | Open College No. 33 | Stephen Hicks
description:
The fall of the Soviet Union was a long time ago.  Venezuela, Cuba and North Korea are far away.  Socialism fell out of favor, but it is attractive to the young again.  But what do they believe that socialism is about?  What arguments against socialism might they find convincing?

Dr. Hicks would like to ask young socialists two questions: what does socialism mean to you? and what is the appeal of socialism?

He then looks at some of the positions people offer for their attraction to socialism:

1) Opposition to the current system: money, power and its cronyism,
2) Moral idealism-thinking of others first, altruism, selflessness,
3) Modern, scientific centralized management of the economy,
4) Free stuff socialism,
5) Robust communalism-putting society first,
6) Prioritize the needs of the poor and weak: welfare statism,
7) Resource management-environmentalism,
8) Emotional commitment.

description:
Campus activism has a long history.  However, generation to generation the grievances change.  One generation ago, it was: "Speak Truth to Power!"  Now it seems to be: "F*** truth and grab power!"

Where do the ideas come from?  Are they kidding?  Are these grievances legitimate?  

In this podcast, Dr.. Hicks dismisses the snowflake terminology for these activists and instead discusses seven factors that indicate their actions are mature and calculated.

title: Hazony Attacks the Enlightenment | Open College No. 31 | Stephen Hicks
description:
In a 2019 PragerU podcast, historian Yoram Hazony makes eight arguments against the Enlightenment, but in doing so, he is engaged in some distortion.

He argues the Enlightenment was not abrupt.  There were precursors of their thought in earlier centuries.  He argues Rousseau, Kant, Marx and the Nazis were "of the enlightenment."  He argues its rejection of tradition is a bad position.  He  argues reason was idolized as infallible, making it akin to religion.

Professor Hicks, in this podcast,  looks at and critiques each of Hazony's arguments, providing context and clarity.

For some time, Professor Hicks has been doing a philosophical analysis podcast on a wide range of contemporary topics.  It has been available on a number of other platforms.  It is now being offered on YouTube as well.  Its mission is to “ to explain the chaos.”

title: War, Socialism and William James | Open College No. 29 with Stephen Hicks
description:
In this podcast, Dr. Hicks takes a critical look at William James' 1910 essay "The Moral Equivalent of War."

In that essay, James discusses man's historical propensity for war and violence and wonders if that urge can be put to better social use.  Hicks is critical of James' one-sided negative history of man and his favorable attitude towards the enslavement of all for the benefit of the state.

For a detailed examination of William James' "The Moral Equivalent of War" see:  https://youtu.be/SZlSzf6fOF4

title: Should we Blame Keynes for Everything? | Open College No. 28 | Stephen Hicks
description:
John Maynard Keynes was the most influential economist of the twentieth century.  In his The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money, published in 1936, he argued that deficit spending during an economic downturn would create demand and eventually encourage supply.  Once the economy recovers, the deficits should be repaid.   Deficit spending has been the norm for the past ninety years, but the deficits are rarely repaid.  

In this podcast, Dr. Hicks looks at Keynes' theory and how it has been implemented.  How close is current Keynesian practice to original Keynesian economic theory?

For some time, Professor Hicks has been doing a philosophical analysis podcast on a wide range of contemporary topics.  It has been available on a number of other platforms.  It is now being offered on YouTube as well.  Its mission is to “ to explain the chaos.”

title: I Love Money. You should Too. | Open College No. 27 | Stephen Hicks
description:
Is money evil? Is it the root of all evil?  Are the rich parasites? Do they exploit others? Behind every fortune is a crime!  Is that true?  Many critics on the right and the left believe so.

In this podcast, Dr. Hicks looks at the critics of money and the rich.  He compares money to books for portability and storage value.  His discussion includes a look at passion as a source of evil.  On a practical note, without money, how would we obtain things we cannot produce ourselves?  Pope Francis, Honore de Balzac, Jean Jacques Rousseau, Thomas Piketty and Karl Marx make an appearance.

title: A Century of War. Why?
description:
The twentieth century was a violent century.  World War I, World War II, the Cold War, the Korean War and the Vietnam War involved multiple combatants and Dr. Hicks argues that the cause/source of the carnage is surprisingly philosophical. 

His focus is on the thought of British thinkers John Locke, Adam Smith and John Stuart Mill as well as the German thinkers, Georg Hegel, Karl Marx and Friedrich Nietzsche..

Stephen R. C. Hicks, Ph.D., is Professor of Philosophy at Rockford University, USA, and has had visiting positions at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C., University of Kasimir the Great in Poland, Oxford University’s Harris Manchester College in England, and Jagiellonian University in Poland.

title: Is Postmodernism neo-Marxist? | Open College No. 23 | Stephen Hicks
description:
In this podcast, Dr. Hicks discusses the relationship between Marxism and postmodernism.  After he looks at the political commitments of the major postmodernists, he looks at how aligned these thinkers happen to be with Marx's ten key features of scientific socialism: 

1. Reductive materialism
2. Logic of history (laws of history)
3. Universal scientific necessity
4. Economics is most fundamental
5. Adversarial (zero-sum) understanding of the world
6. Oppression and exploitation 
7. People shaped by economic forces
8. Violent revolution will be necessary
9. Class distinctions will fade
10. From each according to his ability to each according to his need

He concludes by looking at the influence of Jean Jacques Rousseau on the postmodern movement.

For some time, Professor Hicks has been doing a podcast on a wide range of contemporary topics.  It has been available on a number of other platforms.  It is now being offered on YouTube as well.  Its mission is to “ to explain the chaos.”

Stephen R. C. Hicks, Ph.D., is Professor of Philosophy at Rockford University, USA, and has had visiting positions at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C., University of Kasimir the Great in Poland, Oxford University’s Harris Manchester College in England, and Jagiellonian University in Poland.

description:

In this episode Dr. Hicks turns to the subject of entrepreneurial living and meaning in our lives.  Now and then, we all think about the meaning of life.  Is our life merely a series of obligations? Or a random collection of events?  Is it a quest?  Is it a journey? Does it have meaning?

title: Is Envy Worse in a Free Society? | Open College No. 11 | Stephen Hicks
description:
For some time, Professor Hicks has been doing a podcast on a wide range of contemporary topics.  It has been available on a number of other platforms.  It is now being offered on YouTube as well.  Its mission is to “ to explain the chaos.”

Is a free and open society more susceptible to the dangers of envy? We are all familiar with the claim that socialism is simply based on envy.   Yet, some have argued that envy is, in fact,  worse in a free society because a free society leads to greater inequalities. This point was argued by Jean Jacques Rousseau and also, John Rawls.

Prof. Hicks looks at both positions as well as taking a glimpse at levels of envy in past, primitive cultures and small modern communities where comparison is relatively easy.  He concludes by looking at positive reasons for attention to social comparison.

Stephen R. C. Hicks, Ph.D., is Professor of Philosophy at Rockford University, USA, and has had visiting positions at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C., University of Kasimir the Great in Poland, Oxford University’s Harris Manchester College in England, and Jagiellonian University in Poland.

title: Bhopal Disaster: Subsidized Chaos | Open College  No. 10 |Stephen Hicks
description:
For some time, Professor Hicks has been doing a podcast on a wide range of contemporary topics.  It has been available on a number of other platforms.  It is now being offered on YouTube as well.  Its mission is to “ to explain the chaos.”

The December 3, 1984 Bhopal Chemical Plant disaster is the worst human-caused environmental catastrophe in history.  An estimated 16,000 people died.
 
The story we have been told about the tragedy is: In the name of profit, a large American multinational corporation neglected safety; as a result, many people were killed or injured.   Is it true though?

Dr. Hicks looks at the company and its record of safety practices and the local and national politics on the ground and reaches a different conclusion.

description:
For some time, Professor Hicks has been doing a podcast on a wide range of contemporary topics.  It has been available on a number of other platforms.  It is now being offered on YouTube as well.  Its mission is to “ to explain the chaos.”

title: Your Sex Life Under Socialism  | Open College No. 7 | Stephen Hicks
description:
For some time, Professor Hicks has been doing a podcast on a wide range of contemporary topics.  It has been available on a number of other platforms.  It is now being offered on YouTube as well.  Its mission is to “ to explain the chaos.”

If human beings are the most important means of production, and socialism means collective ownership of the means of production, then socialism means collective ownership of human beings. And if human beings are produced by sexual reproduction, and socialism is about state-management of production, then socialism means state-management of sex.

Stephen Hicks looks at the thought of Robert Heilbroner, Friedrich Engels, Alexandra Kollantai, Franz Hamburger and Wilhelm Reich  on issues of sex and family in this podcast.

title: Nietzsche’s Sister and The Will to Power | Open College No. 6 | Stephen Hicks
description:
For some time, Professor Hicks has been doing a podcast on a wide range of contemporary topics.  It has been available on a number of other platforms.  It is now being offered on YouTube as well.  Its mission is to “ to explain the chaos.”

Friedrich Nietzsche collapses in the streets of Turin, Italy in 1889.  He is 44 years old.  He never recovers.  He had been working on what may be his magnum opus.  Enter Nietzsche's sister.  Her  name was Elisabeth Förster-Nietzsche.   In 1901, under Elisabeth's direction, an edition is published with the title "The Will to Power." In 1930, Elisabeth, before they came to power, became a supporter of the National Socialists. She was a believer. Looking back, what should we make of this work?

The most widespread view after World War II has been to dismiss The Will to Power on the grounds that it was distorted by Elisabeth: either by omissions, or by selective highlighting, or, possibly, additions. 

In this podcast, Dr. Hicks looks at the facts, the extent of Elisabeth's influence on the work and offers his thoughts.

title: Conservatives: Get over the Dark Ages | Open College No. 5 | Stephen Hicks
description:
For some time, Professor Hicks has been doing a podcast on a wide range of contemporary topics.  It has been available on a number of other platforms.  It is now being offered on YouTube as well.  Its mission is to “ to explain the chaos.”

Some say, there was no Dark Age! It's a travesty to slander the Medieval era! There was lots of good stuff, great achievements in the Middle Ages. 

But the mainstream view, by contrast, has been that the Middle Ages were a dark period in Western history. Life expectancy was low. Literacy was low and declining. People were by-and-large superstitious, ignorant of science and of the larger world around them.

So who has the better argument?  Good historians break the Medieval into two parts: from 400 CE to 1000 CE and that from 1000 CE to 1500 CE time periods. The 400-1000 time period really was awful, and that's what the "Dark" ages are about. That's where the debate really is and should be focused.

Stephen R. C. Hicks, Ph.D., is Professor of Philosophy at Rockford University, USA, and has had visiting positions at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C., University of Kasimir the Great in Poland, Oxford University’s Harris Manchester College in England, and Jagiellonian University in Poland.

title: Is Dugin Fascist, Neo Marxist, or What? | Stephen Hicks at the Museum of the Second WW
description:
Alexander Dugin claims that Fascism and Communism are dead—and that Liberalism is evil. So a fourth political theory is needed for Russia’s future. What alternative does he propose? And is it really a fourth alternative—or a re-packaging of old illiberal ideas? 

Pr. Hicks reviews the ideas of Alexander Dugin, taking care to discuss their development over time in such works as "Fascism-Borderless and Red"(1997) and "The Fourth Political Theory"(2009).

This talk was given at the Museum of the Second World War in Gdansk, Poland on December 15, 2022.

title: The Dim Ruins of the Enlightenment? | Open College No. 4 | Stephen Hicks
description:
For some time, Professor Hicks has been doing a podcast on a wide range of contemporary topics.  It has been available on a number of other platforms.  It is now being offered on YouTube as well.  Its mission is to “ to explain the chaos.”

“We live today amid the dim ruins of the Enlightenment project, which was the ruling project of the modern period.” -Enlightenment's Wake by John Gray.  There is a persistent claim that our culture is a failure. It is made by pessimists of all stripes, including many postmodernists.

Pr. Hicks will look at this claim in some detail by looking at the achievements of the Enlightenment in light of its promised progress. He will also examine some of the reasons that might explain the pessimism found amongst some intellectuals.

title: Conservatives are not Free Market Capitalists | Open College No. 3 | Stephen Hicks
description:
It is a commonplace belief that conservatism favors free-market policies.

Yet when Pr. Hicks surveys the thought of conservatives on free market capitalism, including the ideas of Robert Bork, Irving Kristol, Russell Kirk, Pat Buchanan, Alexander Solzhenitsyn and George Will, such a connection is not the case.

Conservative and capitalist differences are fundamental.

For some time, Professor Hicks has been doing a podcast on a wide range of contemporary topics.  It has been available on a number of other platforms.  It is now being offered on YouTube as well.  Its mission is to “ to explain the chaos.”

Stephen R. C. Hicks, Ph.D., is Professor of Philosophy at Rockford University, USA, and has had visiting positions at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C., University of Kasimir the Great in Poland, Oxford University’s Harris Manchester College in England, and Jagiellonian University in Poland.

description:
For some time, Professor Hicks has been doing a podcast on a wide range of contemporary topics.  It has been available on a number of other platforms.  It is now being offered on YouTube as well.  Its mission is to “ to explain the chaos.”

title: "Only a God Can Save Us" | Martin Heidegger & Nazism | A Film by Jeffrey Van Davis
description:
Martin Heidegger is considered to be the most profound thinker of the Twentieth century. His magnum opus, Being and Time was published in 1927 and had the equivalent impact on philosophy that Einstein's  theory of relativity, published in 1906, had on physics and Freud's theory of personality, published in 1902, had on the field of psychology.

In May 1933, Heidegger, Germany's most famous philosopher, joined the Nazi Party and became the first Nazi Rector of a German University.

In an interview in Der Spiegel in 1976, Heidegger reiterated his distaste for democratic society and modernity. His final words of despair: Only a God Can Save Us.

Timestamps:

01:41 Memorial and recollections
07:00 Messkirch
10:55 Early life
14:04 World War I

30:30 The speaker is Alfred Denker of the Martin Heidegger Archiv.

title: Rene Descartes | Meditations on First Philosophy | Philosophers Explained | Stephen Hicks
description:
Philosophers, Explained covers major philosophers and texts, especially the great classics. In each episode, Professor Hicks discusses an important work, doing a close reading that lasts 40 minutes to an hour.

René Descartes(1596-1650) was a French scientist, philosopher and mathematician.  He was the developer of analytic geometry.  The Cartesian coordinate system used algebra to describe geometrical figures.

In this episode, Dr. Hicks discusses the first and second meditations from Rene Descartes' 1641 book, Meditations on First Philosophy. Descartes asks" Of what can I be certain?" and reaches a negative conclusion.

description:
Philosophers, Explained covers major philosophers and texts, especially the great classics. In each episode, Professor Hicks discusses an important work, doing a close reading that lasts 40 minutes to an hour.

In this episode, Dr. Hicks discusses the  essay "The Doctrine of Fascism" (1932) jointly written by Italian dictator Benito Mussolini and Professor Giovanni Gentile.

Benito Mussolini(1883-1945) was an Italian journalist and politician.  He was the founder and leader of the National Fascist Party in Italy.  He was the Prime Minister of Italy from 1922-1943.  Giovanni Gentile (1875-1944) was an Italian neo-Hegelian philosopher.

title: Ayn Rand | "Man's Rights" | Philosophers Explained | Stephen Hicks
description:
Philosophers, Explained covers major philosophers and texts, especially the great classics. In each episode, Professor Hicks discusses an important work, doing a close reading that lasts 40 minutes to an hour.

In this episode, Dr. Hicks discusses the novelist-philosopher Ayn Rand's essay on individual rights.

Ayn Rand (1905-1982) emigrated from the Soviet Union to the United States as a young woman.  She wrote four novels, including The Fountainhead and Atlas Shrugged.  In the course of writing these novels, she developed her rational, realist philosophy which she named 'Objectivism."

title: Friedrich Nietzsche | On the Genealogy of Morals | Philosophers Explained | Stephen Hicks
description:
Philosophers, Explained covers major philosophers and texts, especially the great classics. In each episode, Professor Hicks discusses an important work, doing a close reading that lasts 40 minutes to an hour.

Friedrich Nietzsche (1844-1900) was a German philosopher. He wrote mostly in an aphoristic style.  He is most famously known for his thoughts on good and evil, master-slave morality, the Uber Mensch, the will to power, ressentiment and the death of God.

In this episode, Dr. Hicks discusses the First Essay in Nietzsche's work, On the Genealogy of Morals(1887), focusing on the nature of good and evil and master and slave moralities.

title: Immanuel Kant | Critique of Pure Reason | Philosophers Explained | Stephen Hicks
description:
Philosophers, Explained covers major philosophers and texts, especially the great classics. In each episode, Professor Hicks discusses an important work, doing a close reading that lasts 40 minutes to an hour.

In this episode, Dr. Hicks turns to Immanuel Kant and his 1787 second edition of Critique of Pure Reason, arguably the most foundationally influential work in modern philosophy. I focus on the Preface to that edition, famous for his conclusion that "I have therefore found it necessary to deny reason to make room for faith."

title: Beyond Woke Academia | The Patriotic Philosopher talks to Stephen Hicks (Podcast)
description:
This conversation took place on May 4, 2022, between Dr. Michael Robillard (The Patriot Philosopher) and Dr. Stephen Hicks.  

The topics they discussed included Machiavellian postmodernism, the aftermath of the "Sokal Hoax" and the prospects of engagement with the woke left.

Dr. Michael Robillard is a U.S. Army veteran and analytic philosopher who has held research positions at the U.S. Naval Academy, University of Oxford, and the University of Notre Dame.  

He is the author of: Don't Go to College: A Case for Revolution co-authored with Timothy J. Gordon, Regnery Publishing and Outsourcing Duty: The Moral Exploitation of the American Soldier co-authored with Dr. Bradley J. Strawser, Oxford University Press.

The Patriot Philosopher podcast can be found on Apple Podcast and www.michaelrobillard.com

00:00 Introduction
01:08 Dr. Hick's background
04:35 What do you mean by Machiavellian postmodernism?
15:07 How sincere are those who use postmodern tactics?
18:03 Analytic philosophy and the "Sokal Hoax."
27:37 Engagement with the woke left 
32:21 Canada's Bill C16 and civility
37:45 What does the current woke environment mean for free speech?
40:06 Have the foundations of classical liberalism led us to this woke moment?
49:28 Pragmatic complaints in favor of far-right statism?
52:02 Predictions and Prescriptions?
55:30 Closing message


Stephen R. C. Hicks is Professor of Philosophy at Rockford University, Illinois, USA, Executive Director of the Center for Ethics and Entrepreneurship, and Senior Scholar at The Atlas Society.

Other links:  

Website: http://www.stephenhicks.org/ 
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/SRCHicks

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/stephenhicksphilosophy/

description:
This is the second part of a discussion that originally took place on June 3, 2020, between Dr. Stephen Hicks and Lucas Skrobot on his YouTube channel.  The first part of this conversation can be found here:  https://youtu.be/48gawwP5uII

The conversation ranged from postcolonial Botswana vs. Zimbabwe, to socialism in Norway and Sweden and pockets of socialism in city life in the US.

Lucas Skrobot tears down current global and cultural events giving you the history and context you need to expose underlying world views driving cultural agendas. Ultimately connecting back to why it should matter you, what we can learn, and how to order our lives and society to own the future.

title: Do Free Societies Need Postmodernism? | A Debate | Thaddeus Russell and Stephen Hicks
description:
This was a public debate hosted by the Soho Forum in New York City on June 17, 2019. 

It featured Stephen Hicks, a professor of philosophy at Rockford University, arguing for the negative, and author Thaddeus Russell arguing for the affirmative.  Soho Forum director Gene Epstein moderated.

00:01:15 Introductions
00:01:50 Arguing for the Affirmative: Thaddeus Russell
00:17:24 Arguing for the Negative: Stephen Hicks
00:33:20 Five-Minute Rebuttal: Thaddeus Russell
00:38:35 Five-Minute Rebuttal: Stephen Hicks
00:43:47 The Moderator-Gene Epstein-asks questions
00:57:31 Audience questions
01:27:40 The audience votes

Thaddeus Russell is the author of the 2011 book, A Renegade History of the United States.  He argues that cherished American freedoms come from the selfish desires of ordinary people. Renegade University, founded by Russell, offers courses on diverse subjects from postmodernism to the history of martial arts.

Stephen R. C. Hicks is Professor of Philosophy at Rockford University, Executive Director of the Center for Ethics and Entrepreneurship, and Senior Scholar at The Atlas Society.  He is the author of Explaining Postmodernism: Skepticism and Socialism from Rousseau to Foucault (2011) and Nietzsche and the Nazis (2010).

Daxton Page hosts a podcast called Logocentric.  In this wide-ranging discussion with Stephen Hicks they talked about such modern philosophers, Jean Jacques Rousseau, Immanuel Kant, Fredrich Nietzsche, Herbert Marcuse. Topics ranged from subjectivism, primitivism, socialism, agrarian socialism, modernity, postmodernism, statism, collective action, critical theory and the practical side of philosophy.

title: Postmodern Critique of Liberal Education | Pope Lecture 2019 | Stephen Hicks
description:
This lecture took place at Clemson University on October 30, 2019.

It was sponsored by The Clemson Institute for the Study of Capitalism, America's premier academic institution dedicated to studying the moral foundations of capitalism and a free society.  Their YouTube channel is at: https://www.youtube.com/c/clemsoncapitalism/featured 

In this lecture, Dr. Hicks gives a historical overview of key educational ideas from Ancient Greece, the modern era and up to these postmodern times.  He discusses key ideas from each of the periods.  Classical education stressed discipline, obedience and rule following, while modern thinkers, like John Milton, Galileo, John Locke and Montaigne stressed independent judgment and the power of reason.  

He then examines the contemporary scene in which reason is seen fundamentally as an instrument of white male power by such postmodern thinkers as Richard Rorty, Andrea Dworkin, Jacques Derrida, Henry Giroux and Chandra Mohanty, who argue that the classroom has become a political and cultural site--a center of power struggles--and that education must be turned to activism.

He concludes with a look at the empirical data which vindicates the role of reason in light of the advance of political freedom and economic prosperity in the last 200 years.

00:02:22 The postmodern vanguard: Foucault, Lyotard, Derrida, Rorty 
00:09:22 Modern and postmodern 
00:12:22 Modernism and the Enlightenment 
00:22:50 Postmodernism versus the Enlightenment 
00:25:06 Postmodern academic themes 
00:29:51 Postmodern cultural themes 
00:33:17 Why postmodernism? 

CHAPTER TWO: The Counter-Enlightenment Attack on Reason
00:38:11 Enlightenment reason, liberalism, and science 
00:40:20 The beginnings of the Counter-Enlightenment 
00:47:05 Kant’s skeptical conclusion 
00:50:56 Kant’s problematic from empiricism and rationalism 
00:57:36 Kant’s essential argument 
01:05:26 Identifying Kant’s key assumptions 
01:10:55 Why Kant is the turning point 
01:17:37 After Kant: reality or reason but not both 
01:22:21 Metaphysical solutions to Kant: from Hegel to Nietzsche 
01:27:49 Dialectic and saving religion 
01:35:55 Hegel’s contribution to postmodernism 
01:37:28 Epistemological solutions to Kant: irrationalism from Kierkegaard to Nietzsche 
01:48:49 Summary of irrationalist themes 

CHAPTER THREE: The Twentieth-Century Collapse of Reason
01:50:10 Heidegger’s synthesis of the Continental tradition 
01:55:54 Setting aside reason and logic 
01:59:42 Emotions as revelatory 
02:05:16 Heidegger and postmodernism 
02:09:19 Positivism and Analytic philosophy: from Europe to America 
02:15:13 From Positivism to Analysis 
02:18:54 Recasting philosophy’s function 
02:22:04 Perception, concepts, and logic 
02:29:36 From the collapse of Logical Positivism to Kuhn and Rorty 
02:31:25 Summary: A vacuum for postmodernism to fill 
02:34:33 First thesis: Postmodernism as the end result of Kantian epistemology

title: What is good? | Philosophy for Real Life (2 of 22) | Stephen Hicks
description:
Now and then, we ask ourselves big questions, tough questions, philosophical questions.

Philosophy for Real Life is a series of 22 short videos looking at such questions as: what is philosophy?  do I need philosophy?  what is ethics?  what is art?  what is virtue?

Stephen R. C. Hicks is Professor of Philosophy at Rockford University, Illinois, USA, Executive Director of the Center for Ethics and Entrepreneurship, and Senior Scholar at The Atlas Society.

title: Michael Rectenwald interviews Stephen Hicks
description:
The following conversation took place on June 2, 2021.

00:00 Intro
00:51 Is the current contemporary left Rousseauian?
03:56 Anti-reason, anti-truth movement
06:39 Postmodernism as a crisis of faith in Marxism
12:05 Herbert Marcuse & the Frankfurt School
14:13 Where are we now?

52:43 Higher education shake-up?
55:18 The prestige factor of social justice
58:33 Advice to younger people interested in grad school
1:02:07 Advice to intelligent people concerned about the culture

Michael Rectenwald, Ph.D., TheAntiPCProf, is a free market public intellectual. He was a Professor of Liberal Studies at New York University, where he taught from 2008 to 2019. He is the author of nine books, including Google Archipelago: The Digital Gulag and the Simulation of Freedom (2019). Springtime for Snowflakes: “Social Justice” and Its Postmodern Parentage (2018), Nineteenth-Century British Secularism: Science, Religion and Literature (2016), Academic Writing, Real World Topics (2015), and Global Secularisms in A Post-Secular Age (2015). 

He can be found at:  https://www.michaelrectenwald.com/.

title: What Business Ethics Can Learn from Entrepreneurship
description:
Dr. Stephen Hicks reads his article "What Business Ethics Can Learn from Entrepreneurship," originally published in The Journal of Private Enterprise 24(2), 2009, pp. 49-57.

An ethical analysis of the difference between creating $10,000,000, embezzling $10,000,000 and giving $10,000,000 away.

title: Lockean versus Rousseauian Narratives | One on One with Nicholas Capaldi:
description:
Dr. Stephen Hicks, professor of philosophy at Rockford University, interviews Nicholas Capaldi, who is the Legendre-Soulé Distinguished Chair in Business Ethics at Loyola University, New Orleans. 

They discuss the prevalence of Lockean liberty narratives and Rousseauian equality narratives in contemporary society.

title: Nietzsche and the Nazis by Stephen R. C. Hicks (Full Audiobook)
description:

00:00 Part 1. Introduction: Philosophy and History/1. Fascinated by history

title: Explaining Postmodernism by Stephen Hicks: Full Audiobook
description:
*****See timestamps below for easy browsing*****       
This audiobook edition of Explaining Postmodernism is read by the author.

To listen to a specific chapter of the audiobook on YouTube, visit: http://www.youtube.com/user/EPAudiobook

To download MP3s of the audiobook or for more information, visit Dr. Stephen Hicks's Explaining Postmodernism page:
http://www.stephenhicks.org/publications/explaining-postmodernism/

To purchase the book on Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/Explaining-Postmodernism-Skepticism-Socialism-Rousseau/dp/0983258406/ref=sr_1_1?dchild=1&keywords=explaining+postmodernism&qid=1624466040&sr=8-1

Timestamps:
00:00:00 EXPLAINING POSTMODERNISM 
00:00:25 CHAPTER ONE: What Postmodernism Is 
00:02:22 The postmodern vanguard: Foucault, Lyotard, Derrida, Rorty 
00:09:22 Modern and postmodern 
00:12:22 Modernism and the Enlightenment 
00:22:50 Postmodernism versus the Enlightenment 
00:25:06 Postmodern academic themes

title: Rent Control 1: The Standard Buyer/Seller Relationship
description:
Professor Stephen Hicks presents the arguments pro and con about the ethics, economics, and politics of rent control.  See the next video here: https://youtu.be/T9Dq0nvdWfQ

Recommended Supplemental Readings:

Walter Block, "Rent Control," The Concise Encyclopedia of Economics. An economist's survey of the economic arguments pro and con. http://www.econlib.org/library/Enc/RentControl.html

San Francisco Tenants Union. "Rent Control: Coverage & Rent Increases." An information page about how rent control regulations are administered in San Francisco. 
Wikipedia, "Rent Control." Overview of the history of rent control and arguments over rent control in the United States.  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rent_control_in_the_United_States

To view the rest of this case study and more, go to our Case Study channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/CEECaseStudies

title: One on One with Douglas Rasmussen on Philippa Foot's "Natural Goodness"
description:
Dr. Douglas Rasmussen, our final guest speaker of Spring 2010, gave two lectures at Rockford College recently. Dr. Rasmussen is professor of philosophy at St. Johns University in New York, has authored numerous articles in a variety of journals, and is coauthor (with Douglas J. Den Uyl) of Norms of Liberty: A Perfectionist Basis for Non-Perfectionist Politics (2005). 

Here, Dr. Stephen Hicks interviews Dr. Rasmussen about his talk on Philippa Foot's book Natural Goodness, given to Professor Klein's Ethical Theory class.
